poem:
Titling Errors and Factual Marrow

In this daily grind of black and white,
Rico Lewis morphs to Henry, overnight.
Football's fleeting fame, errors recite.
Yet pales to bacon swaddled in fright.

Pork to beef, unnoticed sleight,
Journeying from lab to plate in twilight.
Cells, once quietly hidden from sight,
Now parade as Scotch delight.

Our mistakes herald a world, re-written,
Truths smudged, in ink, free and unbidden.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Corrections and clarifications • A Premier League roundup referred to Rico Lewis in the section on Brentford; we meant Rico Henry (Saturday’s talking points, 12 February, p37). • The headline and picture caption of an article (Fortnum’s unveils scotch eggs made with lab-grown pork, 3 February, p7) said that the meat was pork. In fact the lab-grown meat surrounding the quail egg was beef mince as it had been grown from a cell taken from". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
